item.title: New laptop
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:8, topic:452046”]Then why does mine score so high? I certainly know that my integrated i5 graphics chip will not score that high, I’ve used it before when I didn’t have drivers for my dedicated and it was just terrible.
And it doesn’t always score equal, if I overclock the card it’ll often differ.[/quote]

As I said in my previous post:

MistaBigBoss:

First generation HD Graphics are really not worth to be called GPU’s, maybe Windows doesn’t even use those for drawing the GUI. And that maybe is a probably because your benchmark displays the same score on both graphical categories.

I probably was too vane on that statement, but what I meant was, since you’re stuck up with a first generation Intel i core processor, your processor uses Intel HD Graphics 1000. But that’s really nothing compared to the second gen Intel HD Graphics 2000/3000. Those second gen ones are powerful enough to be used as the GPU for the windows GUI. The Intel HD Graphics 1000 however is not. That is why it is most likely ignored by Windows for use as a GUI processing unit. Therefore Windows uses your dedicated GPU for the GUI and that is why your score is so high. And to make things more obvious, you got the same score on both graphical categories, indicating that the same chip is used on both tests.

I hope you get my point now.

Read full topic

item.title: New laptop
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Then why does mine score so high? I certainly know that my integrated i5 graphics chip will not score that high, I’ve used it before when I didn’t have drivers for my dedicated and it was just terrible.
And it doesn’t always score equal, if I overclock the card it’ll often differ.

Read full topic

item.title: New laptop
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:5, topic:452046”][quote author=MistaBigBoss link=topic=554925.msg4065527#msg4065527 date=1343852406]

http://i50.tinypic.com/2n6vjgk.png well i think yours a little bit better whit graphics of games
[/quote]The reason we second generation Intel (Sandy Bridge) guys have a low Graphics score is because the Intel Graphics GPU (built-in on the CPU) is used for drawing the Windows GUI. Our real GPU only kicks in on more graphics thirsty applications.

True, however the windows experience index benchmark does still use the dedicated GPU if one exists, mine is only a first generation but it still beats that, it looks likely that he doesn’t have a dedicated GPU, my laptop wasn’t even expensive…[/quote]I’m sorry but you’re wrong. When Intel HD Graphics is available, Windows uses that for the GUI and for benchmarking the GUI. And he certainly does have a dedicated GPU because his Gaming graphics score is 6,3.

First generation HD Graphics are really not worth to be called GPU’s, maybe Windows doesn’t even use those for drawing the GUI. And that maybe is a probably because your benchmark displays the same score on both graphical categories.

My laptop has a GT540M and a Intel HD Graphics 3000, I get 6,7 on Gaming graphics but 5,7 on the GUI.

I don’t know but my theory supports everyone’s results.

Read full topic

[/quote]The reason we second generation Intel (Sandy Bridge) guys have a low Graphics score is because the Intel Graphics GPU (built-in on the CPU) is used for drawing the Windows GUI. Our real GPU only kicks in on more graphics thirsty applications.[/quote]
True, however the windows experience index benchmark does still use the dedicated GPU if one exists, mine is only a first generation but it still beats that, it looks likely that he doesn’t have a dedicated GPU, my laptop wasn’t even expensive…
